awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Taking the reliability of Cenozoic boron isotope pH and pCO2 reconstructions to the next level
awd_abstract_narration:
If anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions continue to increase unabated, the continued accumulation of this gas in the atmosphere will warm Earth's climate via the greenhouse effect, while the dissolution of CO2 in the surface ocean makes seawater more acidic. Although historical CO2 levels and global warming are reasonably well documented for the past few decades, scientists' understanding of climate and particularly ecosystem sensitivity to much higher CO2 levels is limited and greatly impedes accurate projections of future changes. Earth history can aide scientists in improving their understanding, by providing much longer geological records of variations in past seawater chemistry and their associated ecological responses, if any. This research aims to provide fundamental constraints on surface ocean acidity and atmospheric CO2 levels throughout the past 65 million years, when a number of climate shifts containing important information about oceanic and atmospheric chemical changes occurred. The research will combine surface ocean acidity reconstructions from geochemical information stored in the fossil shells of plankton organisms, as well as computer model simulations of ocean carbon chemistry. In addition to informing scientists and policy makers about the impact of rising atmospheric CO2 levels on global climate, the outcomes of this study are also of great value to paleoecologists, who want to understand the effect of ocean acidification on marine life. The study will support the research of two graduate students at Columbia University and University of California at Riverside, and will provide training in carbon cycle modeling to interested researchers .

Specifically, the project will measure the boron isotopic composition (delta11B) recorded in fossil foraminifera shells to reconstruct past seawater-pH and, by inference, atmospheric CO2 levels. Earlier studies using this approach have only been able to reconstruct relative shifts in seawater-pH and atmospheric CO2, because slight differences in the delta11B recorded by individual foraminifera species complicate the application of this proxy to the distant past, as most ancient foraminifera species are now extinct. In addition, a second parameter (e.g., alkalinity) of the marine carbonate system is needed to accurately calculate atmospheric CO2 levels from surface ocean chemistry records, but researchers have not yet found a reliable geochemical indicator for alkalinity in ocean sediments. This research aims to overcome these limitations, by (1) cross-calibrating modern and extinct planktic foraminifera species, (2) refining Earth system model estimates of surface ocean alkalinity, and (3) deriving a refined and self-consistent reconstruction of Cenozoic pCO2 from boron isotopes and modeled alkalinity. In addition to the low resolution 65-million year paleoreconstruction anticipated by this study, the cross-calibration of vital effects on foraminiferal delta11B and improved alkalinity estimates from geochemical modeling will facilitate future studies of absolute rather than relative pH and pCO2 in the past.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The rising concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere does not only warm the planet via the greenhouse effect, but also acidifies seawater as more and more CO2 dissolves in the ocean. These two consequences of anthropogenic fossil fuel burning and land use changes can have significant consequences for global climate and marine life. However, although historical CO2 levels and global warming are reasonably well documented for the past few decades, scientists’ understanding of climate and particularly ecosystem sensitivity to much higher CO2 levels is limited and greatly impedes accurate projections of future changes. Earth history can aide scientists in improving their understanding, by providing much longer geological records of variations in past seawater chemistry and their associated ecological responses, if any. This research aimed to provide fundamental constraints on surface ocean acidity and atmospheric CO2 levels throughout the past 65 million years, when a number of climate shifts containing important information about oceanic and atmospheric chemical changes occurred. Specifically, this project measured the boron isotopic composition (d11B) recorded in fossil shells of ocean surface dwelling plankton (called foraminifera) to reconstruct past seawater acidity and, by inference, atmospheric CO2. While this approach has been applied before, researchers have only been able to reconstruct relative shifts in seawater acidity and atmospheric CO2, because slight differences in the d11B recorded by individual foraminifera species complicate the application of this approach to the distant past, as most ancient species are now extinct. This research aimed to overcome these limitations, by comparing and calibrating the d11B of modern and extinct species in the same sediment samples, and then tracing this comparison further back in time with the continued comparison of calibrated extinct species to non-calibrated extinct species. While this study originally aimed to complete this approach over the past 65 million years, the pandemic hampered data collection for two years, and although samples have been prepared for the entire study interval, data have so far only been collected for the past 30 million years. The improved calibrations suggest past atmospheric CO2 was much higher than today's concentration of ~420 parts per million (ppm) and ranged between 500 to 570 ppm after the onset of major ice sheet development on Antarctica (i.e., during the late Oligocene, ~30 million years ago), and 420-700 ppm during the early Miocene (i.e., ~20-18 million years ago). These data broadly agree with climate models for the late Oligocene, but exceed estimates for the early Miocene, indicating that further proxy and model validation is required to solidify our understanding of the climate system.  

Broader impacts: One graduate student advanced from a novice paleoceanographer to an independent scientist, gained significant expertise in foraminiferal geochemistry, including sample selection, foraminifera taxonomy, geochemical sample analysis, data processing, interpretation and paper writing. He presented his work at several conferences, either as posters or talks that were well received by his audience. He also applied for fellowships, postdoc and faculty positions, and in 2022 was awarded the Johana Resig Fellowship of the Cushman Foundation and Columbia University's Kluge Graduate Fellowship. In 2023 he accepted an offer for a faculty position at Williams College in Mystic (CT). These applications did not only hone his proposal writing skills but the fellowships also allowed him to gain important experience in teaching and mentoring three undergraduate students, including two Columbia students and one NSF sponsored summer intern who is black and will enter the PhD program at Yale in 2023. He guided these students in picking foraminifera, preparing and analyzing samples for trace elements and stable isotopes, and summarizing the research findings in written reports, and conference presentations. In summary, he is now a well-rounded scientist who is well prepared to start his independent research and teaching career.
